comments.commentBody: Oh. Lord, I have long known he was Eddie Munster, but forgot Eddie was a little wolf-man!!! Thanks.
He was in the Senate, not the House, maybe.

I Donna know Italian, but I liked this puzzle. It was a tiny bit harder then some Mondays, but still fell fairly quickly.

I add my thanks to our substitute blogger. Well done Mr. Gaffney. Welcome back, Deb.

Mac

Your argument is specious. As long as Ryan and any Randite believes that country's problems are solely about about the level of government spending, they will sink the country faster than we sank the Bismarck during WWII.

The problem the U.S. has is that its economic base has been outsourced and under-invested for a generation. It's expenditures on infrastructure, R&D, education and job training is puny relative to the size of its economy.

While it is true that the government budget is large, it is no larger as a % of the economy now than a generation ago. Yet, the economy once grew faster and was more stable. The truth is that it is not HOW MUCH you spend but WHAT you spend it on and HOW it gets dispensed that matters. The GOP can complain all they want about social programs but the GOP also spent a gazillion dollars bailing out the fraudulent financiers and on two unnecessary wars. Could these trillions of dollars been better used?

If you cut the budgets without making economic reforms (isn't this what the same moralists are telling the PIIGS?) that end TBTF and rent seeking that consumes an ever larger % of the economy, our election system and court system you will NEVER solve the problem of the budget deficits or pay down the national debt.

Q.E.D.
With his widow's peak, Ryan looks like Eddie Munster, grown up.

Tadpole - perhaps I didn't make it clear enough that by "seriousness" I meant "intellectual seriousness", which is what Professor Krugman is talking about in this article. I can't imagine that you are suggesting that passing something in the House of Representatives is a benchmark for that.

Probably you don't remember that the conservative funding of think tanks was a reaction to their unhappiness with (and lack of control over) the universities back in the Seventies and Eighties. The problem is, you can't buy intellectual integrity, no matter how much money you have, but think tanks (right or left) are designed to do exactly that. And the right is wildly better funded.
Tadpole? Who knew the NYT has it's very own concern troll. Spare me your sentiments. Save them for Red State , Drudge and the Breibart Report

@Tadpole
Your comment indicates you don't understand how the Senate works. Unfortunately under the current rules a small cabal of 40 senators can stop any legislation.

The fact that we are even having this discussion about Ryan's "seriousness" shows just how good a return the right wing is getting on its decades-long investment in the propaganda agencies otherwise know as "conservative think-tanks". It's a nice demonstration of market dynamics: they created a huge artificial demand for congenial intellectuals, and lo and behold, the supply appeared.

These things have all the trappings of scholarship - journals, abstruse papers, fellowships and so on. The problem is that everything that comes out is essentially work-done-for-hire, which due to its sheer volume dominates a large part of public discussion, regardless of how light-weight or ill-founded it may be.

This is an ugly dynamic which shows no signs of getting any better.

Excellent ideas - excellent for the workers, for the economy, & for society! A win-win solution - isn't that what we used to consider ideal?

Yes, this would stimulate demand - which is the engine that drives the economy. It would improve quality of life because people would have more time to spend with their families, in recreational & fitness activities, continuing education - & volunteering.

And it's been proven that flex hours, 4-day weeks & vacations actually increase productivity.

But at this point, getting back to a true 40 hour week would be "progress." The fact is, most people now work much longer hours, because with so many people laid off, many of those still working are doing the jobs of 2 or 3 people - & are afraid to complain. Many of us now are expected to stay in touch with the job by email & cell nearly 24/7.

Yes, the 1% & business people would "go crazy" - even though this is the kind of progress that would benefit all of society, including business bottom lines.

But it seems some people can never be happy with their own success - they can't stand to see anyone else do well.

That's why the 1% would rather see our entire society go down the drain rather than allow the 99% to share in the wealth we helped to create. & it's why the tea party types would rather vote against their own interests rather than see anyone else benefit.

Michael, many people have gotten an education, and are poor.

The current winner-take-all economy threatens every job that can be automated, roboticized, digitized, or delivered over the internet.

Those whose jobs are safest: plumbers, HVAC techs, electricians, nurses, nannies, child care providers, salesmen and people with great promotional skills, electrical engineers with hands-on skills in instrumentation and electrical work, robotics technicians, and highly skilled software designers.

Ironically, many of these jobs don't require a four-year college degree. If I were advising my child on how to prepare for the future, I'd urge him or her to consider some profession that requires:

1) hands on skills in addressing the needs of permanent, highly costly structures (high-rise buildings, dams, etc).

2) and, coming in a far distant second place: hands on skills in addressing the medical needs of people. But, even that is somewhat iffy as more and more medical insurers are sending their patients abroad for the most common and expensive surgeries.

What's next? Shipping granny to offshore retirement homes?

3) American citizenship. The FBI and the CIA have yet to outsource their agents and security analysts.
brawn over brains. no wonder America's lagging.. We have a dislike of jobs that involve us using our brains and those who do those jobs are called " Nerds "

Dear Average,

every invention increases human possibility while reducing the work involved. For example, the wheel allowed people to move things more easily.
That evolved into creating hand carts, horse carts, cars, motorcycles..computers, ipads, iphones, robots.. We didnt get here because of stupid greedy corporations but because humanity has a subconscious destiny to become smarter and better at everything. Humanity has a built in destiny to morph itself into cyborgs and make its existing organic form obsolete. Resistance is futile : )

thank you.
\signed
I, ROBOT

Once government revenues dry up, the government withers - & civilization as we know it ends.

That's what happened to the Roman Empire - once it could no longer pay for its troops & to maintain its infrastructure, it was over - & the Dark Ages began.

What did the wealthy elites do at the onset of the Dark Ages? They withdrew to country estates, behind high walls, protected by paid guards. The 99% of the day were left to fend for themselves & were often at the mercy of well-armed marauders. Literacy & learning declined.

Sound familiar?

Yes, robots are efficient, productive, & create wealth for their owners - at least, temporarily. Problem is, robots don't buy anything & they don't pay taxes.

Yes, civilization may well reorganize & human ingenuity may well find other ways to make a living. But that may take a very long time - & in the meantime, we can look forward to generations of chaos & suffering - i.e., the new Dark Ages.

Markoff always embraces every aspect of emerging technology as the holy grail of the new.

You have to understand that here in Silicon Valley it is a culture of a huge number of top dogs, who already made their marks, viewing to control their past.

They don't want to give up the ghost of their achievements and be merely foot notes in history.

There is not a whole lot of retirement except by women, and not me.

Thus, the push to deliver astounding numbers is the goal, not astounding deliverances from the evils of world famine, flooding, disease, ignorance, lack of housing, or from ultra violet rays that are giving the fish off the Great Barrier Reef skin cancer.

Here in silicon valley, it's a whole new meanness. Frankly I don't like it but from where Markoff comes from, it's his spear and shield = to make the news that every one will read.

"Opposition is likely fruitless"

It's not as if we won't have choices. We're likely to have more choices than ever. Mass production reduced prices to consumers, and robots will enable further price reductions. Anyone who wants to pay more will still be able to hire other humans to hand-produce whatever they want, just as is true today. You can purchase factory-made clothing or have your choice of hand-made. The same is true of most everything, such as factory produced eggs, farmed fish, or you can buy organic and local.

Not to mention that "never touched by human hands" will be an advertising slogan with broad appeal.

I am NOT advocating for genocide of any kind - neither am I advocating for "eugenics" in the sense of limiting childbirth for "others" or any specific groups.

I AM advocating for ALL humans across the board - of all ethnic groups, nationalities, socioeconomic status, etc. - to control and limit population worldwide.

Let's not allow the horrors of 20th century genocide to deter us from the NECESSITY in THIS century to limit population growth worldwide in order to avoid the suffering that will ensue - which in fact, is already happening.

The FACT is, our earth & its resources are finite - & as much as technology has improved the quality of life for millions of people, it's already eliminating the jobs of millions more - & clearly will eliminate the need for the labor of billions in the future.

Would you prefer to have no restrictions on population growth - & allow billions more humans to be born who will never have enough food, housing, or opportunity for education and gainful employment?

Wouldn't it make more sense - wouldn't it be more rational & humane to limit population growth by encouraging & if absolutely necessary, mandating contraception use?

Why can't we have any rational discussion about contraception & population control without someone bringing up the "boogyman" of "eugenics"?

If we don't control global population growth, we'll have another kind of "eugenics" - population control by starvation, disease, & violence. Is that what YOU wish for?
But of course, how can they be consumers if they have no means of earning money to buy anything?

We already HAVE an educated workforce - including many engineers and IT workers who are unemployed or underemployed.

Do you have any specific recommendations for how we can "adapt" to an economy in which millions of skilled, well-educated people are already superfluous, & which, in the near future, will require millions FEWER workers?

Hope there will be plenty of work on Romney's plantations - or on our future Mars colonies.

No -- that glass has a big leak in the bottom.  You are ignoring the pretty much inevitiable reality that -- with the rapid development of artificial neural networks -- in the not-so-distant future the robots will be designing and building themselves.

The unions are NOT to blame. Greedy corporate leaders & capital owners are to blame for offshoring manufacturing to places where wages & working conditions are at 19th century slave-labor levels - all so the CEOs can earn wildly overinflated salaries - & the corporations can earn 10 billion instead of 5 billion.

It seems the inconvenient FACTS that our economy & society are suffering here in the U.S. - our infrastructure is suffering - & our once-great nation is devolving into a third-world, third-rate crumbling empire - doesn't bother these greedy 1%ers one bit.

The FACT is, our nation was at its greatest & our economy strongest when unions were strongest - enabling millions of ordinary Americans to make a living wage, in safe working conditions, & made it possible for them to own a home & a car, provide for their kids' education - & retire with a comfortable pension.

What we need is to revitalize unions and the labor movement - & apply costly PENALTIES to companies that offshore labor - along with tax INCENTIVES to those who keep jobs in the U.S.
I got it! Theft on a grand scale. looting will become the thing, and flash crowds can appear at selected stores near you to loot, kill, maim, and otherwise have a great day. Oh boy, can't wait.

Then, what to do with humans?

There is a new craker on the market called SOYLENT GREEN.

Cornelia, I can afford the products from China, especially the bamboo (ecologically great stuff) toothpicks to clean chicken I can't afford from  my ever-widening teeth due to bone lose in my lower jaw.  There are still some things a good American home will simply not be without.

taking a cue from former Japanese business practices, we could have just-in-time tubal ligation, or tubal ligation on demand by robotic surgery.
Sadly, J L, we in the US will never agree to easing the population for any reason. They don't pay any interest at the sperm bank, so people just spend theirs willy-nilly.

Wow!  Did everyone think this was a Superbowl weekend or what?  I can't recall a weaker bunch of openings than this. I'm especially dumbfounded over the lack of business for ParaNorman.  The reviews were pretty good and the storyline would seem to hold appeal for kids (boys in particular).  No competition from pre-sold titles like Ice Age or Madagascar.  Are people finally rejecting the expensive habit of paying jacked-up prices for superfluous 3D?
Nobody deserves any penalty for pot, except perhaps the drug warriors who have held back medical research into this scientifically interesting and virtually harmless plant for 75 years.
